results.title: Splash
results.creator_credit: Brian Grazer, Touchstone Pictures, Buena Vista and Ron Howard
results.brief_description: A romantic comedy fairytale about a most unlikely liaison between a beautiful mermaid (Daryl Hannah) and a New York businessman, Allen Bauer (Tom Hanks). The two first meet when Allen (as a young boy) is rescued from drowning by the lovely mermaid, but it is many years later before the two are reunited on land in New York and our mermaid has transformed into Madison with legs in place of her fishy tail. Madison not only tries to hide her identity from Allen but she also has to keep her legs away from water - or her telltale fin will return. Added to this, Madison has also captured the interest of an obsessed scientist (Eugene Levy). Light-hearted entertainment with great support from John Candy as Allen’s brother Freddie Bauer.

results.title: Spirogyra: structure and life functions
results.brief_description: The unaided eye sees Spirogyra as green masses of slimy intertwining filaments. The microscope reveals detailed cellular structures, including nucleus, cytoplasm, chloroplasts and pyrenoids - the length and diameter of a spirogyra cell, and in a culture we observe growth and sexual reproduction.

results.title: Spirits of the forest; Year of the Gagadju
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Papua New Guinea. Wildlife, Division of, David Parer, Ivo Burum and Jeremy Hogarth
results.brief_description: Spirits of the forest looks at the Birds of Paradise in Papua New Guinea and the unique relationship they have with the highlanders. The people believe they gain the special qualities of the birds by wearing their feathers in ceremonies. This episode was written by David Attenborough. “Year of the Gagadju” looks at Kakadu as the traditional homeland of the Gagadju tribe. This is an account of how they divide the year into six seasons, reading the changes around them. The Gagadju are determined that their traditional culture will not be lost for future generations. Both programs are narrated by Sandy Gore.

results.title: Spirits of Havana
results.creator_credit: Peter Starr, ONF | NFB, Bay Weyman and Luis O. Garcia
results.brief_description: ‘Spirits of Havana’ follows a pair of Canadian jazz players, Jane Bunnett and Larry Cramer, who trek annually to Cuba to collaborate with the local musicians there. Of course, like its recent antecedent, ‘Buena Vista Social Club’, ‘Spirits of Havana’ ends up celebrating the conviviality of Cuban people and culture and the integral role that music and rhythm plays in their lives. Shots of bustling Havana city streets or the bountiful Cuban countryside, overlaid with traditional Cuban music, punctuate this documentary and strongly hint at the Canadians’ love affair with this place. Extended recording sessions with a variety of local musicians from Bobby Carcasses, Amado Dedeu and Pancho Quinto to world famous Afro-Cuban rumba groups like Los Munequitos and Los Naranjos to Desandann, a Haitian group, reveal rich cross-cultural collaboration in action. The Canadians ensure it’s a two-way exchange when they carry out their educational and resource initiative by donating instruments to the local, under-resourced music conservatories and teach the students the world of jazz. Though lacking the cinematic splendour of ‘Buena Vista Social Club’, ‘Spirits of Havana’ is moving for its celebration of Cuban music, culture and history and for its testament to the possibility of cross-cultural understanding and exchange.

results.title: Spirits from the past
results.creator_credit: Hugh Burnett and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Looks at the claims that famous men and women from the past are still working creatively with people alive today. Three people speak about their experiences and beliefs, and claim to be in touch with dead musicians; receiving new music from many composers such as Liszt, Chopin, Beethoven, Brahms and Stravinsky.

results.title: Spirited away (Special edition) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Toshio Suzuki, Studio Ghibli and Hayao Miyazaki
results.brief_description: Often referred to as the Japanese Walt Disney, it is soon obvious while watching master Japanese animator Hayao Miyazaki’s “Spirited away” that the Disney reference point is mostly inadequate in understanding what you’re about to experience. Part mythic odyssey, part children’s fable, “Spirited away” is a wonderful and awe inspiring fantasy film that takes place in the most unexpected of places, a Japanese bathhouse for the gods. At the centre of this surreal world is Chihiro; a feisty ten year old girl who lands in this strange world when her parents decide to stop for a break at a seemingly abandoned amusement park on the way to their new home. In a classic fairytale touch, the parents greedily succumb to mystical temptations (in the form of a banquet of food which appropriately turns them into pigs), leaving the helpless Chihiro to fend for herself. With the onset of night, the amusement park transforms into a meeting place for spirits, demons and gods, which is ruled over by the crazed Yubaba. Chihiro must now find her place, learn the rules and earn her keep in this twilight world of stink gods, giant babies, witches and dragons. Like Miyazaki’s previous animation feature “Princess Mononoke”, “Spirited away” offers complex notions of good and evil, right and wrong, which is ultimately the main departure point between Miyazaki’s multilayered world and Walt Disney’s reassuring land of monochrome sentiment.

results.title: Spirit of trees
results.brief_description: Writer, broadcaster and environmentalist Dick Warner presents this comprehensive documentary on tree facts, crafts and lore. “Old oaks”: Dick and entomologist Ted Green examine oak trees and beetles, bugs and fungi play an important role in the maintenance of a healthy ecosystem. Dick also visits Glenstal Abbey in Ireland, where Brother Anthony explains his passion for forestry, and Brother Ciaran demonstrates his interest in using fallen branches for commercially viable wood-turned hand-crafts. In Part two, “Native trees”, Dick travels to the Highlands of Scotland to examine efforts to restore native woodlands and rehabilitate dead and dying areas through the Findhorn Foundation’s award winning “Trees of life” program. Focuses on the collection and treatment of seeds, and how careful management of these natural resources will benefit both people and the environment in the future. In Part three, “From wild woods to town gardens”, Dick and the woodland expert Oliver Rackham discuss the concept of the wild wood as opposed to the plantation, and go in search of rare species of native trees. Dick then compares the wild wood to the town garden, examining why people often overlook native trees in urban spaces. With Simon Hodge from the Forestry Commission, he scrutinises examples of good and bad tree planting, and offers general advice to people wishing to plant trees. In Part four, “A Dying breed”, Dick visits Bill Hogarth, one of the last remaining coppice woodsmen in the Lake District, and reveals the commercial potential in this old form of woodland management. Dick also speaks to Walter Lloyd, who has restored the ancient tradition of making charcoal (and wooden tent pegs) from coppice wood. In “The Folklore of Trees”, filmed in Ireland and England, Dick explores the perpetuation of customs and superstitions incorporating trees that can be traced back to pagan times, and looks at modern spirituality and rituals associated with tree worship. He visits a Money Tree, holy wells and the sacred trees that guard them, examines the folkloric traditions connecting trees and May Day, and hears first hand accounts of the superstitions surrounding the rowan, or “fairy” tree. In “Rare Trees”, Dick visits the island of Socotra in the Indian Ocean to find out what drives botanists to conserve rare specimens such as the Desert Rose, Dragon’s Blood, wild pomegranate and Cucumber trees. Back in England, he discovers similar preservation efforts being conducted with old varieties of fruit trees, particularly the Plymouth pear and the Brampton apple, and discusses some of the techniques being used to prevent their extinction. In “History of Trees”, Dick tracks down ancient trees and the importance of tree ring analysis for both dating objects for archeologists and documenting environment alteration. He visits the remarkable Bristlecone pines in the White Mountains, California, the ancient Limes of Coniston, North West England, and looks at the significance of the placement of ancient Yew trees in relation to churches. In the final episode of this series, “Future of Trees”, Dick considers the modern usage of trees by looking at the versatility of Willows and their prudent use as opposed to the exploitation of the Redwoods in the Sierra Nevada Mountains, California.

results.title: Spirit of the Tall Ships
results.brief_description: SPIRIT OF THE TALL SHIPS traces the historical voyage of the Polish Tall Ship, Dar Mlodziezy and the USA Coast Guard’s Egle to Australia, and the adventures of four young Australians who took part in these epic journeys.
results.description: SPIRIT OF THE TALL SHIPS traces the historical voyage of the Polish Tall Ship, Dar Mlodziezy and the USA Coast Guard’s Egle to Australia, and the adventures of four young Australians who took part in these epic journeys.

results.title: Spirit of the Renaissance
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John Barnes
results.brief_description: Explores the intellectual and artistic climate of Florence during the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries using scenes from the daily life of a contemporary Florentine. Discusses the lives and influence of Petrarca, Alberti, Leonardo Da Vinci and Savonarola. Film uses dramatization, contemporary art material with modern day footage of Florence and Rome.
